item.title: COSUST-D-20-00134
item.description:
This short review article offers an excellent summary of scholarship on bureaucratic policymaking. I see two possible directions for revision depending on whether the intended audience is scholars who study public policy or scholars who are unfamiliar with existing public policy scholarship.

The review is concise, accurate, and helpful, but it is not clear if the main purpose is to review scholarship for unfamiliar readers or build an argument of some kind directed at students of environmental policy.

I thus offer two sets of comments, one for the case where this review is intended to be an introduction to the field and another for the case where this review is to be an intervention in our field.

As an introduction to public policy research

If the aim is to bring scholarship on bureaucratic policymaking to a new audience, this will succeed to the extent that readers are unfamiliar with the scholarship reviewed.

If this is the case, the main opportunity to improve the paper is to offer more ties to climate change, or, more precisely, the specific types of policies likely to be confronted by policymakers as they deal with climate change. This is done numerous times, but the role of climate change in this article is somewhat ad hoc, often tacked on to paragraphs reviewing studies, and lacking overarching conclusions. It is often, but not always, clear how the scholarship reviewed relates to climate policy. It is not clear what the ‚Äúmain takeaways‚Äù of this review would be for, say, a scholar of climatology or public opinion who might not be familiar with political science scholarship on political institutions.

That said, the body of the text is an excellent review, and clarifying this framing would only take minor revisions to the abstract and introduction. In particular, I would move the third paragraph of the introduction to the beginning if this is the intended frame.

As an intervention in public policy research

If the aim is to frame a research agenda for public policy scholarship on climate issues, this would be extremely valuable, and the review is a good start, but much more work would be needed. To the extent that the manuscript offers an intervention beyond informing unfamiliar readers of existing work, it is largely confined to the last three paragraphs. Given the potential value of articulating research agendas in this area, such limited advice seems like a missed opportunity.

If this manuscript is to be reorganized around an argument, the abstract and introduction offer two potential framings.

Frame 1. Administrative procedures deserve more attention

First, the authors argue that successful climate policy hinges on administrative procedures. While important and underappreciated in climate politics discourse, this claim will not surprise scholars of political institutions. The counter-argument would be that policy implementation is not important, a position with few, if any, advocates.

The authors do frame their argument for the importance of policy implementation in contrast to scholarly attention on climate attitudes in the first few paragraphs, but they offer no evidence that policy implementation (a) deserves relatively more attention that attitude or (b) is the main ‚Äúbarrier‚Äù to successful mitigation and adaptation. A study of the relative importance of attitudes and administrative procedures would be interesting but far from the current manuscript.

Frame 2. Science-based policy discourse must change

Second, the authors gesture at a critique of ‚Äúscience-based policy.‚Äù I see this as a more fruitful potential intervention. All of the studies reviewed say something important about the political determinants of policy, rapidly dispelling notions that climate policy just needs ‚Äúbetter science.‚Äù Moreover, the authors might build on scholars who write critically about the role of science in administrative procedures like Wendy Wagner. Some empirical evidence is required to motivate this frame:

  1. It is not clear how exactly either scientific claims or claims about the need for better science are influencing policy.

  2. In much of the body of the review, ‚Äúevidence and public input‚Äù are presented alongside each other as inputs into the policy process. There is relatively little about potential conflicts between them.

As is, the review only addresses the usability of climate science in the first few sentences of the introduction and conclusion. There is no direct support for the claim that ‚Äúthe usability-oriented portrayal of climate science use in policymaking is politically and administratively naive.‚Äù Indeed, the authors seem to think that the scholarship they at times seem to critique is invaluable, correct, and crucial, just not the whole ball game. If there is something wrong with this scholarship, other than the fact that it is not political science, I am not sure what the authors think it is.

Research agendas

Beyond framing, what, specifically, should scholars do to advance, unite, or diverge from the many research agendas reviewed? The last three paragraphs of the discussion section pose some interesting research questions. These could be better connected to the body of the review. In the last three paragraphs, the authors pose three sets of questions:

  1. ‚Äúwhose perspectives are sourced, heard, and incorporated in administrative procedures‚Äù
  2. ‚Äúwhether certain procedural mechanisms should eclipse others in climate decision-making‚Äù
  3. ‚Äúhow NEPA‚Äôs procedures have shaped the quality and pace of climate decision-making‚Äù

These are good questions and, if the intent is to launch research agendas on them, the body of the review could be reorganized to focus on what we do and don‚Äôt know about these questions and how climate politics may be similar and different from the empirical contexts of past research. As is, the scope of the review is much broader than the questions posed, and it is not clear exactly how each of the studies reviewed inform or are challenged by climate politics.

item.description:
Clear argument and writing

Great leap in methods

Combines cutting-edge tools to discover patterns + experimental evidence about causal effects

Summary

1. Visual topic model

Conservative media ‚Äì> more image features we might call ‚Äúnight‚Äù (dark, high-contrast)

  • Protestor violence ‚Äì> less efficacy, less support

  • Police violence ‚Äì> less efficacy, less support? ‚Äì

  • Images > words, except for ‚Äúthe police went too far‚Äù

Summary of thoughts:

  • More integration of computer vision and experiment sections?
  • Combine samples for both experiments?
  • What are the mechanisms?
  • What would we find in other contexts?

=> sharp gradients (brightness, contrast), possibly shapes, objects?

‚Äì

‚Äì

Exploring data, testing hypotheses

‚Äútest the expectation that conservative newspapers are more likely to use nocturnal frames‚Äù

Simpler Task: How to measure ‚Äúnight‚Äù in images?

‚Äì

Suggestions:

  1. Inspect topic models with different \(k\)s, pick one with the most ‚Äúnocturnal-looking‚Äù topic.

‚Äì

  1. Identify the ‚Äúmost nocturnal‚Äù topic or topics in many models, average proportions.

‚Äì

  1. Discover patterns, design more direct tests features of interest (observational or experimental)
  • e.g.¬†dark and high contrast images
  1. Model environmental and mood latent feature structure simultaniously with object features

‚Äì

Are image fragments draws from a distribution of ‚Äúnight‚Äù or ‚Äúsomething else‚Äù with a probability that varies by image?

‚Äì

Or are image fragments draws from a distribution of objects that vary (in brightness and contrast) depending on whether they are drawn from a ‚Äúnight‚Äù or ‚Äúday‚Äù image?

‚Äì

‚Äì

If we can model night/day variation, we could identify variation in what is depicted at night and day?

Regardless of exploratory or testing use of topic models, we all should report in appendicies:

  • all topics for models used (e.g.¬†top words via FREX)
  • models with different \(k\)s

What else pops out?

‚Äì

For example, can you recover latent dimensions for

peaceful vs.¬†violent features? - e.g.¬†crowds (‚úì) vs.¬†flames (?)

‚Äì

police violence vs.¬†protestor violence features? - e.g.¬†riot gear objects vs.¬†broken glass objects

(perhaps a better task for CNNs or other supervised methods using object libraries)

Next steps?

  1. Mechanisms

There are a lot of potential mechanisms here. You are clearly thinking about this, but perhaps some of my thoughts about disentangling mechanisms will be useful if you go further down this path.

  1. Other movements

Minor tweaks to this paper‚Äôs framing could leave the door open for different findings for reactionary movement protests.

Variables

Viewer: - disposition (equality, hierarchical structures and need for order) - social context?

What is shown: - violence + intensity + object/direction + against people or property? - protest content?

How it is shown: - color tint?

‚Äì

  • Night

  • Greyscale and redscale?

‚Äúprotest paradigm‚Äù - deviant, threatening, imponent

‚Äì

‚Äì

Valence (?) - negitivity (discomfort, anxiety, linked with crime) - arrousal

Expectations about attitudes

‚Äúhigher levels of hierarchy-enhancing attitudes to be less susceptible to visual frames of violence in protests and to overall report negative perceptions‚Äù

‚Äì

Police violence? (Riot gear, bodies on the ground)

‚Äì

Pro-hierarchy protest? (Swasticas, blue line flags)

‚Äì

Protestor on protestor violence?

‚Äì

Symbolic violence (Guns, flags, symbols)

‚Äì

Property damage vs.¬†violence? - blood, teargas, or ambulance (bodily injury) vs.¬†fire or broken glass (property damage)

Other small notes:

  • I am not exactly sure what ‚Äúfairness‚Äù means on page 5. Perhaps that a perception that there is a problem implies that the status quo is unfair?
  • Minor typo on page 5 ‚Äúparticipation at in social movements.‚Äù
  • On page 10, by ‚Äúinitialized with 12 topics,‚Äù you just mean that you set \(k=12\) or do you mean that some algorithm chose \(k\), but you initialized it with a prior of \(12\)?
  • Figure 3 is labeled ‚ÄúTopics‚Äù‚Äìshould be ‚ÄúNight activity topic,‚Äù right?
  • The intro to section 4 starts with a second lit review. This is unconventional, and the paper may be better integrated by combining
  • On page 24, I would not say that they trust the text more, just that the text undermined a baseline assumption that protestors start violence, whereas the image was more open to interpretation. This is evidence for blame/identity hypotheses over cost-benefit hypothesis.

item.title: The Political Economy of Coal
item.description:

‚Äúaffordability was highlighted by interviewees as the most important objective that shapes energy policies.‚Äù But ‚Äúreliability and security‚Ä¶are a dominant focus in politics.‚Äù

Thus, the coal industry succeeded in influencing national political rhetoric but failed to translate political support into policies needed to maintain profits.

A new puzzle!

???

The argument, part 1

Q1b. Why has it declined?
